definition:
The sequence of polynomials $$\begin{aligned}
\langle P_0(x),\, P_1(x),\, P_2(x),\, \ldots\rangle\end{aligned}$$ with
$$P_n(x) \;:=\; ax^n \qquad (n = 0,\,1,\,2,\,\ldots)$$ is a geometric
sequence and has trivially the properties $$\begin{aligned}
P_n'(x) \;=\; nP_{n-1}(x) \qquad (n = 0,\,1,\,2,\,\ldots)\end{aligned}$$
and $$\begin{aligned}
P_n(x\!+\!y) \;=\; \sum_{k=0}^n {n \choose k}P_k(x)y^{n-k}\end{aligned}$$
(see the binomial theorem). There are also other polynomial sequences
(1) having these properties, for example the sequences of the Bernoulli
polynomials, the Euler polynomials and the Hermite polynomials. Such
sequences are called *Appell sequences* and their members are sometimes
characterised as *generalised monomials*, because of resemblance to the
geometric sequence.

Given the first member $P_0(x)$, which must be a nonzero constant
polynomial, of any Appell sequence (1), the other members are determined
recursively by $$\begin{aligned}
P_n(x) \;=\; \int_0^x\!\!P_{n-1}(t)\,dt+C_n\end{aligned}$$ as one gives
the values of the constants of integration $C_n$; thus the number
sequence $$\langle C_0,\,C_1,\,C_2,\,\ldots\rangle$$ determines the
Appell sequence uniquely. So the choice $C_1 = C_2 = \ldots := 0$ yields
a geometric sequence and the choice $C_n := B_n$ for
$n = 0,\,1,\,2,\,\ldots$ the .\
The properties (2) and (3) are . The implication $(2)\Rightarrow(3)$ may
be shown by on $n$. The reverse implication is gotten by using the
definition of derivative: $$\begin{aligned}
P_n'(x) &\;=\;  \lim_{\Delta x \to 0}\frac{P_n(x\!+\!\Delta x)-P_n(x)}{\Delta x}\\
& \;=\; \lim_{\Delta x \to 0}\frac{P_0(x)\Delta x^n+{n \choose 1}P_1(x)\Delta x^{n-1}+\ldots+{n \choose n-1}P_{n-1}(x)\Delta x}{\Delta x}\\
& \;=\; {n \choose n\!-\!1}P_{n-1}(x)\\
& \;=\; nP_{n-1}(x).\end{aligned}$$
